Posted By: blink182zombies (1/8/2011 3:30:10 PM)
Rating:

posts.post_content:
Swapping an [Ornithopter](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Ornithopter) for an [Inkwell Leviathan](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Inkwell Leviathan)? Repeated recursion of [Sundering Titan](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Sundering Titan)? Yes, and yes again.
  
   
With [Intuition](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Intuition) as a graveyard feeder, welder decks are extremely powerful. I've also had plenty of fun using welder and [Careful Study](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Careful Study).
  
   
This card enables many winning strategies, all for 1 red mana.
  
   
5/5
posts.html:
Swapping an Ornithopter for an Inkwell Leviathan? Repeated recursion of Sundering Titan? Yes, and yes again.

With Intuition as a graveyard feeder, welder decks are extremely powerful. I've also had plenty of fun using welder and Careful Study.

This card enables many winning strategies, all for 1 red mana.

5/5

Posted By: apollogod (12/30/2010 3:49:04 PM)
Rating:

posts.post_content:
@GrimjawxRULES: You missed a word:  
  
"Choose target *artifact* a player controls and target *artifact card* in that player's graveyard. If both targets are still legal as this ability resolves, that player simultaneously sacrifices the artifact and returns the artifact **card** to the battlefield."  
  
I did too on first pass, and thought the exact same thing. But if you notice it refers to "artifact" for the one on the battlefield (because it's a artifact permanent), and "artifact card" for the one in the graveyard (because it's a card in the graveyard of type "artifact"), it makes sense.  
  
And I agree the flavour text rocks. I lol'd when I first read this back in the day.
posts.html:
@GrimjawxRULES: You missed a word:

"Choose target artifact a player controls and target artifact card in that player's graveyard. If both targets are still legal as this ability resolves, that player simultaneously sacrifices the artifact and returns the artifact card to the battlefield."

I did too on first pass, and thought the exact same thing. But if you notice it refers to "artifact" for the one on the battlefield (because it's a artifact permanent), and "artifact card" for the one in the graveyard (because it's a card in the graveyard of type "artifact"), it makes sense.

And I agree the flavour text rocks. I lol'd when I first read this back in the day.

Posted By: djbon2112 (3/15/2011 6:56:35 PM)
Rating:

posts.post_content:
Haha, I love it! This is almost certainly the one Goblin Artificer that nobody would argue is marginal.
  
   
I have loved and collected goblins for a long time... when Urza's Legacy was still relatively fresh and new, I remember seeing so many of these in a vendor's dollar rare box. I looked at the card, thought "Meh... but it's a goblin"... and bought one.
  
   
I still kick myself for that to this day.
  
   
@Grimjaw: Agreed re: flavour text, 100%. The temptation to ask an opponent if they have any ashtrays in their graveyard is just too strong to pass up.

Posted By: GradiustheFox (2/27/2010 7:24:42 PM)
Rating:

posts.post_content:
Pretty amazing, acts as both a rapid-artifact deployer, and you can hose your opponent by swapping his [Sharding Sphinx](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Sharding Sphinx) for his [Ornithopter](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Ornithopter).
  
   
The card is also a goblin, so he gets the benefit of all of that combos for the clan.
  
   
While not perfect for every deck, he is devastating in any deck that is built with him as a component.
  
   
4.5/5
posts.html:

Posted By: Ace_Rimmer (7/13/2009 6:17:08 AM)
Rating:

posts.post_content:
According to the flavor (text), it would make more sense if it read  
  
Choose target artifact a player controls and target artifact card in that player's graveyard *with a converted mana cost equal or less to the converted mana cost of the artifact*. If both targets are still legal as this ability resolves, that player simultaneously sacrifices the artifact and returns the artifact card to the battlefield.  
  
As it is, the flavor text might as well read:  
"*I wrecked your ashtray, boss. But look I made you a metal guy.*"  
  
(Since he apparently is able to do just that, i'm pretty sure he got a promotion after that incident.)  
I mean, damn. If he's got the scrap metal, he can turn a [Darksteel Relic](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Darksteel Relic) into a whole [Darksteel Forge](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Darksteel Forge).  
Now tell me that's not impressive!
posts.html:

As it is, the flavor text might as well read:
"I wrecked your ashtray, boss. But look I made you a metal guy."

Posted By: Mode (10/16/2012 2:09:59 PM)
Rating:

posts.post_content:
Pros compared to [Tinker](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Tinker):  
  
-Only costs {R} to come out, subsequent activations FREE  
-Reusable  
-Destroyed artifacts can be fished back out  
  
Cons compared to [Tinker](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Tinker):  
  
-Does not search library, card needs to be in graveyard. Comboes with [Entomb](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Entomb), [Buried Alive](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Buried Alive), but that requires splashing black  
-Summoning sickness  
-1/1 body dies to absolutely everything and anything
posts.html:
Pros compared to Tinker:

-Only costs {R} to come out, subsequent activations FREE
-Reusable
-Destroyed artifacts can be fished back out

Cons compared to Tinker:

-Does not search library, card needs to be in graveyard. Comboes with Entomb, Buried Alive, but that requires splashing black
-Summoning sickness
-1/1 body dies to absolutely everything and anything

Posted By: Arachnos (8/21/2012 8:25:59 PM)
Rating:

posts.post_content:
I could totally imagine a mirror match between two of these:  
  
"I trade my [Ornithopter](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Ornithopter) for a [Blightsteel Colossus](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Blightsteel Colossus)."  
  
"Well I trade my [Memnite](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Memnite) for a [Mycosynth Lattice](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Mycosynth Lattice), use [Voltiac Key](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Voltiac Key) to untap the Welder, then trade your Blightsteel Colossus for an Ornithopter.  
  
"Well I trade my Ornithopter for a [Dross Scorpion](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Dross Scorpion), use Voltiac Key to untap the Welder, trade your Welder for your [Shifting Wall](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Shifting Wall). It dies, so I untap Welder to trade your Voltiac Key for a Shifting Wall then it dies, so I untap Welder and trade my Ornithopter for a Blightsteel Colossus."  
  
"Screw it, here's a [Lightning Bolt](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Lightning Bolt)."
posts.html:
I could totally imagine a mirror match between two of these:

"I trade my Ornithopter for a Blightsteel Colossus."

"Well I trade my Memnite for a Mycosynth Lattice, use Voltiac Key to untap the Welder, then trade your Blightsteel Colossus for an Ornithopter.

"Well I trade my Ornithopter for a Dross Scorpion, use Voltiac Key to untap the Welder, trade your Welder for your Shifting Wall. It dies, so I untap Welder to trade your Voltiac Key for a Shifting Wall then it dies, so I untap Welder and trade my Ornithopter for a Blightsteel Colossus."

"Screw it, here's a Lightning Bolt."

This is perfect- first of all, to fully appreciate this card, you want to read the Artifacts Cycle books. There are lots of these guys running around doing stuff in the background, and a only a few people realize 'wait, I could use friends like that, lol'.

posts.post_content:
This creature deserved to be ranked among top 3 of one-drop 1/1 creature in the history of magic, it is so insanely broken, yet still being legal for legacy and unrestricted.
  
   
Using [Bazaar of Baghdad](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Bazaar of Baghdad) and [Mass Hysteria](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Mass Hysteria), play your ![0](/Handlers/Image.ashx?size=small&name=0&type=symbol) artifacts and dig your [Darksteel Forge](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Darksteel Forge), [Colossus of Sardia](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Colossus of Sardia), [Phyrexian Colossus](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Phyrexian Colossus), [Platinum Emperion](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Platinum Emperion), [Inkwell Leviathan](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Inkwell Leviathan), [Bosh, Iron Golem](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Bosh, Iron Golem), [Sphinx of the Steel Wind](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Sphinx of the Steel Wind), **[Wurmcoil Engine](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Wurmcoil Engine)**, **[Arcbound Overseer](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Arcbound Overseer)**...
  
   
Or [Nullstone Gargoyle](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Nullstone Gargoyle) if you really hate their control deck
posts.html:
This creature deserved to be ranked among top 3 of one-drop 1/1 creature in the history of magic, it is so insanely broken, yet still being legal for legacy and unrestricted.

Using Bazaar of Baghdad and Mass Hysteria, play your artifacts and dig your Darksteel Forge, Colossus of Sardia, Phyrexian Colossus, Platinum Emperion, Inkwell Leviathan, Bosh, Iron Golem, Sphinx of the Steel Wind, Wurmcoil Engine, Arcbound Overseer...

Or Nullstone Gargoyle if you really hate their control deck
